speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Let us take a closer look at the Precision Sliders. These two controls, Temperature and Top P, are your primary tools for fine-tuning an A I performance.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Temperature controls the creativity or randomness of the voice. Think of it as an energy level.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: A low temperature, below point five, results in a very stable, consistent, and sometimes robotic delivery. This is useful for neutral narration or for fixing a voice that sounds unstable.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: A high temperature, above one point zero, results in a highly dramatic and emotional performance. Use this for shouting or intense whispering, but be aware that it increases the risk of audio glitches.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The recommended range for most natural-sounding speech is between point six and point nine.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Top P, on the other hand, controls the range of possible sounds the A I considers. A lower value leads to clearer, more focused pronunciation, while a higher value allows for more characterful and diverse intonation.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: You can lock the sliders to prevent them from being changed when you load a profile that has different saved values.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: In our next chapter, we will cover the use of in-script tags and punctuation. Please load chapter fifteen.
